Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story:
I sit quietly at the kitchen table, watching my parents move around with heavy steps. Lately, their faces seem more lined, their voices softer, weighed down by something I can’t quite name. I know they count on me to be present, to listen, to help lighten their burdens with small acts of kindness and words of comfort. I want to be the child they need, the one who stays close and offers support, especially now.

But my heart aches with another longing. This year, my friends are going to Hajj, and I have enough savings set aside. It’s a dream I’ve carried for so long—to fulfill this pillar of my faith, to stand in the holy places and feel the closeness to Allah. The opportunity may not come again soon. Yet, if I go, I’ll leave my parents alone when they seem to need me most. If I stay, I’ll miss the chance to answer a sacred call. The weight of both expectations presses on me, and I find myself torn, unable to see a path that doesn’t leave something important behind.
